body: WHEN a regional plan for the New York metropolitan area was published by the Regional Plan Association in the 1960's it called for the development of commercial subcenters within New York City outside Manhattan. It mentioned the 149th Street hub in the Bronx, downtown Brooklyn and Jamaica, Queens. It was silent on the Flushing section of Queens.
title: Perspective: Downtown Flushing; Growing Asian Presence Inspires a Hotel

body: Gary Clinton Rivers, former executive director of the New York City Technical College, who had also been an executive with the Congressional Black Caucus and the David M. title: Gary Rivers, Director At College, Dies at 39

title: Islamic Leader on U.S. Terrorist List Is in Brooklyn

body: Only a few months ago, Dorothy Velasquez was living with her 3-year-old daughter, Veronica, in an overcrowded city-owned shelter in downtown Brooklyn. It disgusted her. The place was filthy, she said, and people took drugs in the open. Hundreds of men, women and children slept everywhere, even in the cafeteria. Miss Velasquez, 24, still lives in a
title: A Heritage of Giving: Remember the Neediest Cases Fund; A Homey Kind of Shelter That Even Throws Parties

body: Holiday Havens The only times I've had Christmas Day dinner away from home, I've eaten in hotel dining rooms. Once at the Copley Plaza in Boston, another at the Plaza Athenee in Paris. I don't remember the menus, I remember the consoling sense of durability in the dining rooms and how holidays seemed to engender an esprit de famille matched only by
title: Diner's Journal

body: Over the last three months, a woman who supervised a school bus carrying handicapped children in Brooklyn sexually abused seven of the students repeatedly, the police charged yesterday. The police said the woman abused the children in the back of the bus while they were on the way home from Public School 38, at 450 Pacific Street in the Boerum Hill
title: Bus Matron Charged in Sex Abuse of Handicapped Students

body: Nine people were slain in New York City in a 12-hour period Monday night and Tuesday morning, as the city continued to race toward a record number of homicides this year, the police said. The crimes ranged from drive-by shootings by drug dealers to cold-blooded executions on lonely roads. In one case, the police said, an uncle was stabbed to death
title: Killing Continues at Record Pace; 9 Slain in 12 Hours in New York

body: Maybe it was Samuel Robinson, a 37-year-old homeless man, who best summed up the spectator appeal of yesterday's marathon. He watched it in Harlem, in front of the Handmaids of Mary Convent at 15 West 124th Street, standing in a soup-kitchen line with dozens of people clapping and screaming at the runners, "Pump it up, man!" and "You can do it!"
title: NEW YORK CITY MARATHON; Support On Street Is Very Generous

body: Hoping to prevent the violence and vandalism that have marred recent Halloweens in New York City, the police have assigned extra officers to patrol around schools and shopping areas today, and special units will be watching for roving bands of youths like those who rampaged through the city's streets last year. title: Police and Schools Try to Head Off Halloween Trouble

body: The Homecrest Presbyterian Church, at 15th Street and Avenue T in Brooklyn, stands only a block from the D train, but the white wooden structure carries its 90 years with an almost rural dignity. Set back from the street behind a lush yard, it is a relic of a time when this part of the borough was passing from farmland to suburban neighborhood.
title: Beliefs

body: To satisfy new budget cuts of $94 million demanded by City Hall, the New York City Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. title: Schools to Cut Hundreds of Jobs To Save New York $94 Million
